abstract: Merlin, an organization that represents independent record labels, announced the settlement; Kim Dotcom, founder of Megaupload, compares the case against him to the case against Iraq before the war.
snippet: Merlin, an organization that represents independent record labels, announced the settlement; Kim Dotcom, founder of Megaupload, compares the case against him to the case against Iraq before the war.
lead_paragraph: A New LimeWire Settlement: An organization that represents independent record companies around the world has settled its lawsuit against LimeWire, the defunct file-sharing service. The size of LimeWire’s settlement payment was not disclosed, but the organization, Merlin, said the amount was “commensurate” with the $105 million settlement the major labels reached with LimeWire last year. (Merlin estimates its members’ market share in the United States at about 10 percent.) Merlin was founded in 2008 partly as a result of the indies’ frustration at not sharing in other industry settlements as well as not getting equity in MySpace Music, as the major labels did.

headline.main: Digital Notes: Indies Settle With LimeWire, and Kim Dotcom Speaks Up

abstract: Having the top show on television presents a rare opportunity for any network, but especially NBC, which has been so far behind for so long.
snippet: Having the top show on television presents a rare opportunity for any network, but especially NBC, which has been so far behind for so long.
lead_paragraph: The cellphone of NBCUniversal’s chief executive, Stephen B. Burke, rang early on the morning of April 28 last year. Alan Wurtzel, the company’s president of research, was so excited that he had trouble speaking. “We got a 5.1,” he finally said. Mr. Burke was at the gym, and given the background noise, he figured he wasn’t hearing correctly. “I said, We got a 5.1 in the key demographic,” Mr. Wurtzel repeated, which meant that Nielsen estimated that 11.8 million viewers in the all-important 18-to-49 demographic had tuned in — a breakout number for a new show.

headline.main: NBC Finds a Winner in ‘The Voice’
headline.print_headline: ‘The Voice’ Shapes Up As a Winner For NBC

lead_paragraph: Andrew Breitbart, the conservative blogger and provocateur who attracted a lot of vitriol from his opponents while alive, was celebrated by colleagues and admirers after his sudden death from an apparent heart attack on Wednesday. A note at the top of the Drudge Report, where Mr. Breitbart once worked, read in part: “I still see him in my mind’s eye in Venice Beach, the sunny day I met him. He was in his mid 20’s. It was all there. He had a wonderful, loving family and we all feel great sadness for them today…”

abstract: The Carlyle Group, a private equity firm in Washington, said Friday that it had acquired an 85 percent stake in Ri Happy, Brazil’s largest toy chain, for an undisclosed amount.
snippet: The Carlyle Group, a private equity firm in Washington, said Friday that it had acquired an 85 percent stake in Ri Happy, Brazil’s largest toy chain, for an undisclosed amount.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group, a private equity firm in Washington, said Friday that it had acquired an 85 percent stake in Ri Happy, Brazil’s largest toy chain, for an undisclosed amount. The firm plans to invest 200 million Brazilian reais ($116.8 million) in the toy retailer over the next three years. “This is a segment with significant growth potential in Brazil,” said Juan Carlos Felix, Carlyle’s managing director for Brazil. Since its first Brazilian investment in late 2009, Carlyle has steadily increased its exposure to the country’s consumer market. It owns major stakes in CVC, a tourism operator, and Scalia, a major Brazilian lingerie retailer. With Ri Happy, Carlyle is trying to find opportunity in Brazil’s fragmented toy market. The company has an online store, 114 brick-and-mortar locations and 2,300 employees.

headline.main: Carlyle Acquires Stake in Brazilian Toy Chain
headline.print_headline: Carlyle Acquires Stake In Brazilian Toy Chain

lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Studios sci-fi movie “John Carter” was a big bust this weekend, Brooks Barnes reports in an article with a headline that says it all — “Ishtar Lands on Mars.” The North American box office total of $30.6 million means that Disney is likely to have to write down its losses on the movie, which cost an estimated $350 million to make and market. Why did Disney keep spending to market “John Carter” when it was clear that the film would not be successful, as Columbia Pictures did in 1987 for Ishtar? The relationships.

abstract: The settlement, which is subject to approval by a judge, would end a six-year-old lawsuit over how the record company’s artists should be compensated for digital downloads.
snippet: The settlement, which is subject to approval by a judge, would end a six-year-old lawsuit over how the record company’s artists should be compensated for digital downloads.
lead_paragraph: Ending a six-year dispute, Sony has offered an $8 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit over royalties for digital music. The case, originally filed by the Allman Brothers and Cheap Trick, was one of the first in what is now a wave of litigation by artists accusing major record companies of underpaying royalties by counting downloads as “sales,” like CDs, instead of as “licenses,” which pay much higher rates. (Royalties might be anywhere from 5 percent to 20 percent for sales, while 50 percent on a license is standard.)

headline.main: Digital Notes: Sony Offers $8 Million Settlement Over Royalties

lead_paragraph: Groupon, LivingSocial and other daily deal Web sites have by most accounts been a mixed blessing for small businesses. abstract: Here are three ways to exit your business productively: reduce, reuse, recycle.
snippet: Here are three ways to exit your business productively: reduce, reuse, recycle.
lead_paragraph: In a previous post I brought up the topic of how failed business transfers can have a negative impact on local economies. I was surprised to see that it ignited several comments containing the term “creative destruction” — the concept that external forces like competition, globalization or technological advances force businesses to either adapt or fall by the wayside. Kodak would be a recent example. But the point I was trying to make about the failure of some small businesses to sell, or otherwise thrive after the owner decides to leave, is not about creative destruction. It’s about something much simpler: waste.

headline.main: Keeping Good Businesses From Going to Waste

abstract: Apple’s market capitalization is larger than all American retail combined, while Google’s ad sales are bigger than all the United States newspapers put together. How ApGoog took over the world.
snippet: Apple’s market capitalization is larger than all American retail combined, while Google’s ad sales are bigger than all the United States newspapers put together. How ApGoog took over the world.
lead_paragraph: The consumer Internet was thought to be a verdant garden where thousands, and perhaps millions, of flowers would bloom. Much of that has come to pass, but the Web turns out to be a mighty fine place for giant redwoods as well. Apple and Google — with a combined market capitalization of about $750 billion — have become so large that they all but blot out the sun, threatening to leave offline businesses struggling in the shadows to survive.

headline.main: Apple and Google: Redwoods in the Web Garden

lead_paragraph: Teenagers and parents who appear in the documentary “Bully” made a personal appeal to Christopher Dodd, the head of the Motion Picture Association of America, to change the movie’s rating to PG-13 from R, The Hollywood Reporter reported. The film, which was produced by Harvey Weinstein, who joined the parents, tells the story of bullying in middle school and high school. It received the R rating because of some of the language used, which is particularly unfortunate, the parents say, because it means those who most need to see the movie, won’t be able to.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Teens From ‘Bully’ Protest R Rating, and Lessons of ‘Kony 2012’

lead_paragraph: To prove insider trading, the government must show that passing the information involved a breach of a duty of “trust and confidence” to maintain its confidentiality. headline.main: The Limits of a Duty of Trust and Confidence

snippet: Anyone who contends that the way to raise federal revenue is to cut marginal tax rates is arguing from ideology, not solid evidence, the economist says.
lead_paragraph: AT least since Calvin Coolidge, politicians have trumpeted the supply-side benefits of cutting marginal income tax rates. Lower rates will unleash economic growth and the cuts will largely pay for themselves — or so it’s often said. Yet careful studies find little evidence of such effects. Perhaps it’s time to reform tax policy based on facts, not worn-out assumptions.

lead_paragraph: Apple announced on Monday that it would at last return some of its cash pile to shareholders in the form of dividends and stock buybacks, at a cost of more than $10 billion a year for the next three years. But it is attracting so much cash — $1 billion a week in the last holiday season alone — that the move will not put a dent in Apple’s coffers.

abstract: The selling of a movie with blockbuster potential is big business, much of it online, as marketing for “The Hunger Games” has shown.
snippet: The selling of a movie with blockbuster potential is big business, much of it online, as marketing for “The Hunger Games” has shown.
lead_paragraph: The marketing effort behind the movie “The Hunger Games” has been a marriage of traditional methods — billboards, magazine covers — and social-media promotions guided by Lionsgate’s marketing division, Brooks Barnes writes. No doubt the film, which opens on Friday, had a built-in advantage because of the many young fans of the book series. Even so, feeding the flame online has been a preoccupation for a year for Lionsgate, with a strategy that included hooking in the blogs, a series of well-timed contests at Twitter and Facebook, a YouTube channel, a Tumblr blog, etc.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Feeding ‘Hunger Games’ Fans, and the Theater of Journalism

abstract: Critics of the JOBS Act, who believe the bill isn’t really about small businesses, fear the debate may be over.
snippet: Critics of the JOBS Act, who believe the bill isn’t really about small businesses, fear the debate may be over.
lead_paragraph: The Senate has taken up the House’s so-called JOBS bill, which ostensibly makes it easier for small companies, and many large ones as well, to seek investment in the capital markets, and there are conflicting and confusing reports about what will become of the House’s handiwork on the Senate floor. Though described as a small-business bill, the House’s legislation, as we reported on Tuesday, eases disclosure and oversight requirements for small and giant corporations alike, and some critics of the House’s work had hoped Senate Democrats would temper some of the JOBS bill’s more controversial provisions.

headline.main: Senate Debates So-Called Small-Business Bill

abstract: There are no options to police conflicts among investment bankers as there are in the law. Indeed, conflicts of interest appear to be almost a cost of doing business on Wall Street these days.

headline.main: How Wall Street Deals With Conflicts

abstract: The ruling by a New Zealand judge leaves open the possibility that millions in assets could be returned to Megaupload’s founder, Kim Dotcom. Also, StubHub opens in Britain and the Beatles arrive on digital jukeboxes.
snippet: The ruling by a New Zealand judge leaves open the possibility that millions in assets could be returned to Megaupload’s founder, Kim Dotcom. Also, StubHub opens in Britain and the Beatles arrive on digital jukeboxes.
lead_paragraph: Judge Faults Police Over Megaupload Raid: In the latest twist in the story of Megaupload, a New Zealand judge has ruled that the police used the wrong kind of order when raiding the home of the site’s founder, Kim Dotcom, leaving open the possibility that millions in assets could be returned to him. Justice Judith Potter of the High Court concluded that in carrying out the raid on Mr. Dotcom’s home in Auckland in January, the police made a mistake by using a restraining order that gave Mr. Dotcom no chance to offer a defense, according to a report by The New Zealand Herald. Justice Potter granted a new order on a temporary basis, but said she would still rule on whether Mr. Dotcom would be get his property back.

headline.main: Digital Notes: Judge Sides With Megaupload Over Police Raid

The title refers to an obscure political party in New York: The Rent Is Too Damn High Party. In the book, Mr. Yglesias argues that high rent — by which he means both rents and purchase prices — is a major drag on the American economy and society. “The real value of Yglesias’s book,” John Mangin wrote at The Washington Monthly’s Web site, “lies in its explanatory power, and in its potential to recast an important issue.”

abstract: “Try to frame it as if it’s already happening,” the coach suggested. “Let’s say I ran into you a couple of years from now and you had achieved all this. Tell me what the business looks like.”

lead_paragraph: At the last meeting of our business group, we were joined by Susan Martin, a business coach who has worked with entrepreneurs for 12 years. Before becoming a coach, she ran her own sweater design and manufacturing company. Based on her experience and those of other entrepreneurs, Ms. Martin finds that owners often become mired in the minutiae of running their businesses, neglecting their long-term visions for their companies. The result can be working in a business that doesn’t meet your needs.

headline.main: A Business Coach Joins the Business Group (and Raises the Vision Thing)

lead_paragraph: The comment on CNN by a senior adviser to Mitt Romney that the candidate would be like an Etch A Sketch, easily resetting his campaign for the general election, became an instant Internet meme. The distraction from the comment, made Wednesday morning, had serious consequences for Mr. Romney, Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg write: it shifted the focus from his argument that he had, in effect, won the nomination with his victory in Illinois on Tuesday. And it diluted the lift he received from the endorsement by Jeb Bush on Wednesday. By the end of the day there were interactive Web sites, mocking Twitter hashtags, a Web ad for Democrats, Sarah Wheaton writes; also, Mr. Romney’s opponents, Rick Santorum and Newt Gingrich, brought Etch A Sketch toys to their campaign events.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: A Serious Turn for Etch A Sketch and the Muppets

lead_paragraph: More Spotify Apps: Last year, Spotify introduced a dozen or so apps to make browsing for music easier on the service (and also to make it look more like iTunes). On Thursday, 12 more apps arrive, most from record labels and distributors promoting their music, including Sony Legacy; the Warner Music Group; Def Jam; and the indies Domino and Matador. Also among the new apps: the Complete Collection, which displays full album artwork and liner notes; TweetVine, which makes playlists from Twitter trends; and Classify, a guide to classical music from X5, a maker of digital compilations.

In the fine print the reports point to rapid expansion of digital services around the world.

abstract: Mr. Kjellgren is president, chief and founder of the Kiwi Collection, which reviews luxury hotels and provides booking services. He once entered a room he thought was his, in which a large man was asleep on the bed.
snippet: Mr. Kjellgren is president, chief and founder of the Kiwi Collection, which reviews luxury hotels and provides booking services. He once entered a room he thought was his, in which a large man was asleep on the bed.
lead_paragraph: BECAUSE I travel so much for Kiwi Collection I have learned not to bring a lot of clothing and other things with me. I can make do with a carry-on bag, even if I’m gone for more than a week or so. My itinerary is such that I jump around either from country to country or to different locations within the same country to review hotels. If my checked bag got lost, no one would ever find me, and I really don’t have time to go buy new clothes if my bag got lost.

lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission released its long-awaited report on privacy on Monday and the results could be bad news for the burgeoning online advertising industry, write Edward Wyatt and Tanzina Vega. The commission wants to regulate data brokers like Experian and Acxiom that collect and sell personal information. It also wants to push the industry to respect the wishes of consumers who not only don’t want to be tracked online but want no data collected on them whatsoever. One technology executive, who declined to be identified talking about negotiations for the government, said that “do not collect is basically death for online advertising.”

abstract: Let people refuse to buy health insurance. A “Do Not Treat” list could be established to assure the cost of that decision was not passed on to the rest of us.
snippet: Let people refuse to buy health insurance. A “Do Not Treat” list could be established to assure the cost of that decision was not passed on to the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: At least some members of the Supreme Court seem to be persuaded by the idea that the government does not have the power to force us to buy health insurance. The whole idea seems specious and anti-free-market to me: if the government could legally enact Medicare for all, and tax all of us to pay for it, why is mandatory insurance not legal? It accomplishes the same thing, while minimizing government control of the health system.

headline.main: How About a ‘Do Not Treat’ List?

abstract: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved a second nuclear plant construction permit in two months after a 34-year hiatus.
snippet: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved a second nuclear plant construction permit in two months after a 34-year hiatus.
lead_paragraph: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 4 to 1 on Friday to approve a plan to build two reactors at a power plant in South Carolina, the second nuclear plant construction permit to be in granted less than two months after a 34-year hiatus. The Scana Corporation plans to build the reactors at the Virgil C. Summer plant northwest of Columbia. The company plans to cover 55 percent of the project’s estimated $10.2 billion cost, with Santee Cooper, South Carolina’s largest power producer, paying the remainder. Based in Cayce, S.C., Scana, which submitted its application to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in March 2008, said its first unit would not begin operating until 2017, about a year behind schedule, because of delays in the commission’s licensing process. The second is expected to start running in 2018.

headline.main: Nuclear Commission Clears Reactors in South Carolina
